Extended Description: Age is an important factor in assessing the risk of heart disease. Generally, the risk increases with age.
Sex can influence the risk of heart disease, with men typically having a higher risk at a younger age compared to women.
Different types of chest pain can be indicative of heart disease, with certain types more strongly associated with cardiac issues.

Description: Resting blood pressure on admission to the hospital
Extended Description: Resting blood pressure is a critical measure of cardiovascular health. High blood pressure is a well-known risk factor for heart disease.
High levels of serum cholesterol are linked to an increased risk of heart disease. Cholesterol levels can indicate the presence of fatty deposits in blood vessels.
Elevated fasting blood sugar levels can be an indicator of diabetes, which is a significant risk factor for developing heart disease.
Resting ECG results can reveal underlying heart conditions such as arrhythmias or previous heart attacks, which are relevant for assessing heart disease risk.
The maximum heart rate achieved during exercise can indicate cardiovascular fitness and potential heart problems.
Exercise-induced angina is chest pain that occurs during physical activity, often indicating that the heart is not receiving enough oxygen, which is a sign of heart disease.

Description: ST depression induced by exercise relative to rest
Extended Description: ST depression observed during exercise can be a marker of coronary artery disease. It reflects changes in the heart's electrical activity due to insufficient blood flow.

Full Name: Slope of the Peak Exercise ST Segment
Description: Slope of the peak exercise ST segment
Extended Description: The slope of the peak exercise ST segment can provide information on the heart's response to stress and is used in diagnosing heart disease.

Description: Number of major vessels (0-3) colored by fluoroscopy
Extended Description: The number of major vessels colored by fluoroscopy can indicate the extent of blockages in the coronary arteries, which is directly related to the severity of heart disease.
Thalassemia is a blood disorder that can affect the heart's ability to function properly. Its presence can complicate the diagnosis and management of heart disease.
The diagnosis of heart disease is the target variable indicating whether a patient has heart disease. This variable is used to determine the presence and severity of heart disease.
